column8: It's hard to even understand that it's a game - there's nothing that tells you what to do. Many times, there are lists of options to choose from, but no indication why I should choose one or the other - in some cases, there were a few options that I would have selected together, but I was only able to select one. I ended up just starting to select answers that I knew would move the game along more quickly because it was really annoying and not at all interesting or enjoyable to play. I really like the idea of the game, but there is no way that this, the way it is designed, is going to help anyone learn anything about going to court.
column10: I was the defendant in a family law case that lasted a number of years. I started with a lawyer, but ended up representing myself, successfully.

column8: At first I didn't understand I was to choose an option, and honestly, I'm still not sure about the first few screens as far as prep work and what would have happened had I answered differently. At one point I wondered about an "all of the above" option.  Also, I think an introduction to the game would be helpful, to describe how it was to be played and what to expect. Very brief though.
column10: Quite. My first experiences probably had to do with me being an expert witness as a School Psychologist testifying about IQ - I was subpoena'd without an attorney preparing me for the case, although I learned a bit from school. Next I worked for CPS so at least weekly wrote and presented reports at review hearings. I also testified and helped DOJ prepare cases for termination of parental rights and worked closely with DAs on sex abuse cases. All were fine, although divorce court is different. I did have an attorney for a matter leading up to the divorce, which resulted in an all day hearing. The Judge had me testify as an expert witness about a psychologist's findings related to my ex-husband since the expert wasn't there. It was strange, and yet felt the same as when on the stand other times. We had some sort of settlement phone call while I was represented and that was difficult as my attorney was in a different city and the Judge in yet another city. For a modification hearing I was represented, although my ex-husband (an attorney and represented) derailed the process. I later had to go back to court when ex-husband filed to modify child support - due to lack of money (his game was to run me out of money), I represented myself. I anticipate having to go back to court again, and still feel exceptionally ill-equipped and mystified by the process. I would be happy to help with this game, as I am passionate about supporting efforts that could improve the system. That said, it would be strange to leave my name and number. Wishing you the very best of luck and thank you for your work :)

column8: At first it wasn't clear that I was supposed to click on one of the choices in the list. This game helps to know that the process isn't simple, that preparing early to avoid surprises is the best thing you can do. The examples of conversation that could take place while before a judge were useful. It would be more helpful if there was more detail in what actually happens while in court. Having a better idea of what happens while standing before a judge would help diminish anxiety about not knowing.
column10: SLR in a Supreme Court custody case opposed a high priced lawyer. I was not successful and my ex now has sole custody and guardianship of our son.

I answered the questions on the assumption of no prior knowledge with court process, other than question 2. I would have learned a lot from this if I had no prior experience through my own (defective) counsel. It would be very useful indeed to those with no knowledge. At the end there was no reference to appealing a judge's order, once issued, which leads people to believe a ruling cannot be challenged. The court fee waiver doesn't seem to be prevalent in Canada - it's very hit and miss, but I can't remember if this is going to be generic for the whole of N. America. Some adaptation might be required.
column10: I had a lawyer who cheated me with family court matters to keep earning fees! I then self represented through motions, hearings and appeals. I have supported many others going through legal process in criminal, non-criminal and civil proceedings at every level of court, even one who applied to the Supreme Court of Canada. Over the last 10 years I have seen too many unrepresented defendants who have no idea how to conduct themselves or how courts work. I am currently writing a self-help book for non-lawyers, so I am very interested in your tool and believe it is long overdue. I hope very much it will be publicly available soon.

At the beginning, explain who each of the people in the game are, and where they are located in the courtroom.  Also, this video seems geared towards small claims and civil cases, but doesn't explain that anywhere.  The procedures are different in most family courts, which should be made clear. Even in civil cases, things vary from court to court, so it may be helpful to have a disclaimer that not all courts have Court Service Centers, not all Courts have you check in at the Clerk's Office, etc. In addition, the game seems to suggest that there is no benefit to reaching a settlement or reviewing a proposed settlement agreement - in many cases, meeting with the other side and working out a settlement can be best for everyone involved.  In some Courts, it is required.

When a member of the public goes to the Court Service Center for assistance the staff will go over the paperwork and inform the person whether or not there are fees associated with the paperwork. If the person responds that he or she can not afford to pay the fees Court Service Center staff will provide the person with that paperwork. Some court locations require proff of income be submitted with the fee waiver so if someone is unsure he or she should call the court before taking a trip to the court. Court Service Center staff will also notarize the forms as long as the person has proper identification. Unlike the game Court Service Center staff would not send a person to the clerk without all the proper paperwork otherwise the person will be going back and forth and that is not good customer service. We do not send people to the clerk or to an attorney to have documents notarize when Court Service Centers provide this service. Please refer to the judical website to see our services. Also the came explains to a person that once he or she receives notice of the outcome of their court case the Court Service Center staff can explain what the order means if he or she does not understand. Explaining a court order might be considered an interpretation of the law and I am not sure that Court Service Center staff are allowed to do "advise". Many judicial districts are large and a person's courtroom assignment may not necessarily be on their court paperwork. He or she can check either the Public Information Desk at their assigned courthouse if there is an information desk or the person can check with the Clerk's office or Court Service Center for the courtroom assignment.
